utterances.speaker: DANA PERINO, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Hello, everyone. I'm Dana Perino along with Kimberly Guilfoyle, Juan Williams, Jesse Watters and Greg Gutfeld. It's 5 o'clock in New York City and this is "The Five." A lot of news unfolding today on the president, the Russia investigation, that payment made to Stormy Daniels and more. There's a new report that the feds wiretapped the phones of Michael Cohen, the president's longtime lawyer who is now under criminal investigation. According to NBC News, calls were allegedly intercepted in the weeks leading up to the raids on his home, offices and hotel room. And at least one of them was between Cohen and the White House. This comes on the heels of Rudy Giuliani's surprising revelations from interviews with Fox News, among them that President Trump reimbursed Cohen for the money he paid out to adult film star Stormy Daniels before the elections, contradicting previous claims he didn't know about that payment. This morning on "Fox & Friends," Rudy tried to calm the storm:

utterances.speaker: RUDY GIULIANI, LEGAL COUNSEL TO PRESIDENT TRUMP
utterances.utterance: He didn't know the details of this until we knew the details of it, which was a couple weeks ago. Maybe not even a couple -- ten days ago. He was definitely reimbursed. There's no doubt about it. This was for personal reasons. This was -- the present had been hurt personally, not politically, personally so much, and the first lady by some of the false allegations, that one more false allegation, 6 years old. I think he was trying to help the family. It wasn't for the campaign.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GIULIANI
utterances.utterance: It was to save -- not their marriage, so much as their reputation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And here's how the White House addressed the subject today:

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Why the president was not truthful with the American people and with (INAUDIBLE)

utterances.speaker: SARAH HUCKABEE SANDERS, WHITE HOUSE PRESS SECRETARY
utterances.utterance: As Mayor Giuliani stated, and I'll refer you back to his comments, this was information that the president didn't know at the time but eventually learned.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: That statement wasn't in reference to the reimbursement the payment.

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: Again, I gave you the best information that I had. And the allegations -- the president has denied and continues to deny--

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: Whether you're in the dark, I think is a fairly simple question, whether--

utterances.speaker: SANDERS
utterances.utterance: I think is a fairly simple answer that I've given you, actually, several times now. I gave you the best information that I had, and I continue to do my best to do that every single day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I'm not sure she had a good briefing today, but not an easy one. Kimberly, isn't it very unlikely that the judges in the criminal case that apparently is being pursued with Michael Cohen would have approved a wiretapped for something like a campaign finance violation for $130,000? I think it's pretty unlikely.

utterances.speaker: KIMBERLY GUILFOYLE, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yes, too much of a stretch, unlikely. Rudy Giuliani also said that he didn't think that he was being, you know, wiretapped, that Michael, that that was occurring as it related to that particular incident.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Look, I think, look, there was obviously some, you know, coordination in terms of what the statement would be. People have said, wait, was this a dumb mistake by what he said? I don't think that he accidentally blurted something like that out. Let's get real. Plus, the tweet that went out was perfectly, like, precisely worded that the president put out as well. So now, they've put this information out there, and I guess it's part of their overall strategy.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And what is the legal strategy then? Just to try to get it out before somebody else does?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah, I think he would preempt it. If you're aware of what you have, and what you know, and what comes to light, that then you become aware of. You handle it, you deal, you preempt and put it out there, otherwise, it looks like you were trying to conceal something.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So, Juan, then I guess the question -- probably in the White House press corps today, was the question of -- well, that this is contrary to what information that the president himself and the press secretary had put out there. She handled it the way she did. And, I think that she did a pretty good job, basically, saying I gave you the best information that I had. She also said in the press briefing that last night, listening to that interview was the first time she heard anything different.

utterances.speaker: JUAN WILLIAMS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: Yeah. You know, you feel for her in that situation, and you would know best. But I just think she's in a very -- what they say, a rock in a hard place. I mean, that's a tough one.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Mike McCurry used to say I'm double parked at a no comment zone.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, and I think part of this, though, that strikes me is that Giuliani was clearly pursuing a legal strategy, Dana, which said that the lawsuit, you know, common cause, committee for responsibility and ethics, was really leading to a campaign finance violation. And they wanted to make it clear that there was no third party that paid for the president, and therefore, had some leverage over the president or potentially could blackmail the president, that this was a personal payment. Didn't come from the campaign, didn't come from the Trump organization, but was from the president. And therefore, they say, this should all go away. But, today, what we hear from these various groups is, in fact, they think their case has been bolstered by these comments, because now we understand the payment was made over time. So basically, it was a loan from Cohen. And then, even Giuliani's language was a little peculiar. He said, funneled through an LLC, a party that was set up by Cohen. And, of course, it was all done right before the election. So, this alleged took place in '06. But, here we are right before the election, and this money is being paid -- it looks like, you know, prima facie case of being done not to save family and the wife from embarrassment, but being done to save the president and his campaign from embarrassment.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK. I just got in my ear -- a little birdie told me that MSNBC, apparently, has a banner up right now that says correction, the feds are monitoring, not listening, to Cohen's calls. So, I guess, perhaps, there wasn't a call that was listened to between the president -- or the White House and Michael Cohen. So, there's just another wrinkle in the story, Jesse, your thoughts?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Iron it out

utterances.speaker: JESSE WATTERS, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: My thoughts. Well, listen, I was on the phone with Michael Cohen trying to book him for Watters' World right before the raid.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: There you go.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Getting that out there. If the transcription ever gets out, and the feds see I was bad mouthing Gutfeld.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So, I think it's government surveillance out of control, wiretapping, monitoring, listening, whatever. When you think about who's been listened to. The President of the United States, campaign manager, his lawyer, his advisor, who've he never met, his general, everyone is listening to these people. And this whole investigation started bipartisan and it's now being investigated partisans. It's crazy. It's totally out of control. I don't understand what's going on. Is it about an FEC violation? I think it's a political situation with the payments -- I mean, a personal situation. If it is political, FEC violation, it's a $10,000 fine.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, actually--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So what? He's just trying to protect his marriage and his reputation.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I had a lawyer on today, Greg, that basically said the two -- even if you were to go forward with a campaign finance violation, it will be a misdemeanor, and you also have to have intent. So, you could imagine that Michael Cohen's defense might be -- well, he's been my client for a long time. I tried to do this. It's not like that they have, like, FEC lawyers on the hotline in order to call and figure it out, which it might be something they say.

utterances.speaker: GREG GUTFELD, CO-HOST
utterances.utterance: I'm going to try to look at this, two ways. As a legal scholar--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, good.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- and as just an American who watches The Five, OK? The legal scholar, if I were looking at this, I'd say, you're allowed to pay settlement. It's nothing to do with collusion. He didn't use campaign funds. Not a big deal. Now, as an American, a human being who watches The Five, we already know this guy is a billionaire playboy who lived in New York for four decades. He's going to lie about sex. Fetch me a thanking couch. It's smelling salt, because I don't care. I don't care. I'm not surprised. I think most Americans watching the show right now care more about policy than porn star tricks. Fact is, voters made a choice. They've made a choice. And the choice turns out to be pretty damn good. When we've get to the B-block, we'll talk about the release of those hostages. I think they would agree--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- that this is a good choice. So, what we're seeing right now is an attempt to reverse that choice by people who are now putting party before country. This is not collusion. They're trying to unseat a president based on some kind of technicality. It's garbage.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I do think, Kimberly, that people are conflating these two things. And I don't think that they're conflatable. The Mueller investigation is over here.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: The Cohen raid is over here, and it's not something that they're trying to unseat the president with. It might be -- maybe it's something else. Like, I don't think that you actually monitor somebody's phone calls because of possible campaign finance violation. It might be a misdemeanor.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: You only get that criminal wiretap, if it is a wiretap--

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: They better not be.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- it's something else. And a federal judge would have to approve.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yeah. I mean, you know what? We've seen enough shenanigans, haven't we? Hashtag, shenanigans. So, none of it would surprise me--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I don't know.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- at this point. But, nevertheless, no, it wouldn't be warrant. So, you're right. On a criminal basis, where is the sufficient evidence to say that this is something that warrants a wiretap, and it would be a complete, out-of-control overreach.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: So then, could it be something else.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, maybe it could be something else, but what we see is enough, enough, we get that the weather is Stormy. We've got it. Let's move on in terms of what is going here, because they're harping on this. It's a Michael Cohen thing. It's -- you know, Avenatti saying there's more to come. That this is, in fact, going to undo the president. They would like to -- either parallel path for some of this to undermine the American presidency to -- turn over rule the election, and that's why they're so invested in it. Like, they've got all their chips in on the table.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: To your point, you say you don't think? It's about impeachment. This is a car with two gears. It's a gear for collusion, and when that doesn't work it switches into Stormy. And when Stormy isn't doing too well, they switch back into collusion. It's about impeachment.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's an impeachment goal by a combination of the media and the Democrats. It's a self-reinforcing--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Well, then, let me ask something, though, because -- well, Juan, you can answer this. Given the polarized nation that we have at the moment, and the politics that it is, you can expect that your political opponents are going to use anything that they can against you.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And so, if Hillary had won, Republicans would be trying to use anything they could against her as well--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Republicans are too soft. They've never play this dirty.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, no, you look at Clinton and Paula Jones. There are parallels.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He was impeached over sex.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: So what? He's had the best ratings he's ever had--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly. We have to call a true-some.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It does.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- as Americans. As people who watch The Five.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: He's being honest, though.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: He's being honest?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Instead what you do is you're going for conspiracy theories. Like, this is about getting the president. This is what the president is doing to himself.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's not a conspiracy when somebody says this is going to end the presidency, this is what Avenatti said.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Avenatti? He's not one of these? He's not Robert Mueller.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, he said he's got information to unseat the president.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: That's so silly. Let me just--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: No, it's what he said.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The other thing that struck me today is that you have Rudy Giuliani also saying that the attorney general, Jeff Sessions, should get involved, and he should end this thing. He should throw Mueller out the door. Meanwhile, Giuliani saying don't go after Ivanka. You can go after Jared--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I understand why he said that though, because there's no evidence of a crime. There is no evidence of obstruction, and there is no evidence of collusion, Juan. That's when you look at the questions that they leaked. There's actually no evidence. The questions are trying to elicit the president for saying something that he was thinking during the time he was making the decision about firing James Comey.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Can we be clear about what they know about those questions. The Washington Post reported that the questions weren't actually written by Robert Mueller.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They were written -- Robert Mueller gave them a range of topics. And Jay Sekulow wrote those questions--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Correct.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and then they got leaked.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Either way. If you have a crime, prosecute it. If you don't have a crime, stop trying--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Fine. OK. So stop trying to undermine the investigation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm not undermining the investigation. The majority of Americans want a second special counsel appointed because of all the hokey pokey.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: The thing that's abusing from a far is the constant aha mode that cable news is in. Every day it's aha. And if you are program to look for an "aha moment," you will hear it whether it's there or not. I'm not looking for an aha. I'm not interested in an aha. So what I saw -- listening to Giuliani, all I heard him really say was that, you know, the president has Cohen on retainer. That covers expenses that he doesn't have to know about because that's how billionaires live. That's not an aha, that's a fact.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Let me just tell you, last night was a stunning moment--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- Giuliani saying that $130,000 directly paid by the president, and Greg, it doesn't strike you?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A 130 if you're worth 10 billion is chunk change, Juan.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, my goodness gracious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You can put the blinders on.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No evidence of collusion of the crime itself. So--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But how would we have that evidence?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So far, those--

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I mean, there was a burglary and a break-in in Watergate. That's what they were investigating, and he destroyed evidence. Trump and his team have not destroyed evidence. They've offered thousands and thousands of documents. Everybody has testified except the president. You have to protect the executive branch. You can't get inside the president's head every time he makes a decision.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's great to see -- it's so funny while this is happening, watching Trump's numbers go up in the general population, and among blacks it's doubled.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Very frightening for Democrats right now. And very frightening to the media that the more they go after this guy, the more they elevate Trump because they're turning him into a victim--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: And they can't switch gears.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They can't switch gears.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: People are saying, not your Democrat. Not your immigrant. There you go.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yeah, that's like -- why did you fire Comey and he says, oh, it was collusion, it was the Russia stuff. Oh, no, says Giuliani. It was because he wouldn't say that he wasn't a target. Wait a minute. It just keeps shifting--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: What they should have done is just say--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And America goes, so what?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Right. He also didn't trust him because he felt like he was being blackmailed when he came in with the dossier that leaked three days ago.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's like mobster behavior.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A hope so.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A major new development on three Americans being held captive by North Korea. Could they be coming home soon? Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Tuesday, 18 Republican House members nominated Trump for the Nobel Prize crediting his peace through strength policies. So, should Trump share the award if indeed he wins? We hear about Kim, Xi and Moon, but what about The Worm? Dennis Rodman who claims Kim Jong-un didn't understand Trump until Rodman gave him "The Art of the Deal" last year. That book led to a change of heart.

utterances.speaker: DENNIS RODMAN, FORMER NBA PLAYER
utterances.utterance: I think that his impression about Donald Trump and the American people, I think he has a change of heart.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, now, Trump is going to meet with Kim, and may be American hostages might be released. This is pretty amazing news. So, we went to CNN and MSNBC for a response.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: No, please. Please don't say that.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They just hate any good news about Trump. So, Rodman may be the Obama administration's most successful diplomat. It makes you wonder, should Obama have sent Peyton Manning to talk to Putin? A-Rod to China? Johnny Manziel to Tehran? Point is anything could have worked as long as they had a copy of that book. They've all would have done better than Hillary and Samantha Power. Ask those three hostages who's a better negotiator: Obama and Hillary, or Trump and Rodman?

utterances.speaker: Now, we all know I have as much chance of winning that award as Trump does. The Euro elites are no different than our elites. They find Trump too unseemly to ever elevate in any way. But, that's the point
utterances.utterance: The exact qualities that turn off Lars in Oslo are what snags Kim. Kim understands the guy who negotiates through power, not platitudes and legacy building. No matter what, Trump and Rodman has gotten us further with this nuclear threat than all the Beltway babblers and eunuchs out there. Maybe they should read the book too. All right, Dana, you're at this table when I called Dennis Rodman a little B-word--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- because he went to North Korea. So, I -- my mea culpa, I think I was wrong, and I should apologize to Dennis Rodman. He's an American hero.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think you should reserve your judgment. I do wonder how John Kerry escaped the monologue.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes. Well, he moves very slow. Yes. You know what he did? He blended into the wooden background and I didn't see him.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So mean.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: No -- who did he take on?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: James Taylor.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: James Taylor over to Paris.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: America was happy because James Taylor was not in the country for a few days.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Play a song. Burst it out.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I do think that -- if in the long run we actually do find a peaceful solution here, which there's a long way to go, from here to there, then, of course, then President Trump should be granted -- awarded, excuse me, the Nobel Peace Prize. I also think that one of the big things, and the reason I don't think Dennis Rodman deserve so much credit, is that the strategic plan to squeeze China, and get China to get little rocket man to do the right thing is the brilliance of this whole plan.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: And who started that, Kimberly? A man named Donald Trump.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Donald Trump, the art of the deal.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A book I didn't read.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: So, we're following this train of thought. Amazing peace and world negotiator, Dennis Rodman equipped with a book--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- was able to--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: All you need.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- change the mind-set of Kim Jong-un.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Making him totally sane and open to the charms of POTUS. And then, he therefore said, you know what, I'm going to stop being a bad actor--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: -- and I'm going to get it together. And I'm going to shake hands and work with South Korea, and I'm going to release hostages, and I'm going to stop running around being little rocket man.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: So, I was thinking, Juan, that you should go to Iran with my book--

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You're right.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- Gutfeld Monologues, and I think that would solve everything.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Might not ever come back. Is that your idea?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's a win-win, either way. It's a win-win, either way.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I mean, what if it work?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It could work. It could work. Anything for Greg, you know that.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We're you hoping Juan gets trap over there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Another hostage we're going to have to rescue.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Thank you.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: We'll get right on it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Jesse could be my seal.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Oh, you're never getting out then.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I'm struck by Dennis Rodman. I just think that's wonderful. We'll have fun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yeah.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But I think you're having fun. And I think that--

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Oh, he's serious.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: But, no, what you said is serious, Kimberly. I mean, come on. So, he took a book and it changed everything? I mean, you know.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It could be.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: We talk about--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- book can change your life.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: But what happened between the book and now? He actually got nuclear weapons.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Well, that's the art of the deal, negotiation.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Besides the Bible, the Art of the Deal is probably right up there in the second best book--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Way to couch that.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Probably. Listen, a few years ago you would have said that Donald Trump and Dennis Rodman, with the support of Kanye West--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- were ending the Korean War, I would have dropped dead. This is incredible--

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Check your pulse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- get Kushner out to the Middle East, I'll say send Rodman.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And then, maybe they can share the peace prize. I think everything is happening for a reason.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Dana, do you think that -- I mean, on a serious point, we you hear of the imminent release of these hostages. What does it mean?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I think it means a couple of things, that Mike Pompeo, when he was there and he actually met with Kim Jong-un, it was probably a condition. And also, John Bolton, the new national security advisor it's like we're not going to -- remember Bergdahl--

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and the trade?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It was like not really a good trade.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: That's not going to happen in this administration. And so, there's no possible way that President Trump would be willing to meet with somebody who was holding Americans hostage in a labor camp. So, in order to make that happen, they have to be released. Two of them had been taken hostage in 2017, one before that, I think 2015. Hopefully they can -- apparently they're at a hotel now. They've been moved from the camp to a hotel. And when we meet them -- I actually think it's going to be very interesting. It will probably take years for us to actually get all the information. But imagine what we might learn from them about how Kim Jong- un actually works. And so, I do want to tap the brakes on this idea that Kim Jong-un should share in a Nobel Peace Prize.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know what's interesting to me--

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He's a horrible person.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- we've had releases before, Dana. We've had releases with -- in '09, I think, with Bill Clinton, and '10 with Jimmy Carter. And so, this is what the people at state and others say, you know, this is part of his behavior. This is how he plays the game. He makes offers. And it's not clear what our strategy is going in.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I like our strategy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I see some people want to celebrate early.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Could you imagine Otto Warmbier, right?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, look at what happened with Otto. GUTFELD: We've got so much to talk about, including Hillary Clinton. You're going to love this. She's a brand-new excuse for losing the election. I love this one, because she might be right. The Five, returns.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: We've heard enough excuses from Hillary Clinton as to why she didn't win the White House. I didn't think there were any more left. But behold, there's another. Here's the latest gem.

utterances.speaker: UNIDENTIFIED MALE
utterances.utterance: You may be the only presidential candidate since World War II that actually had to stand up and say, "I am a capitalist," and you did. Did it hurt you?

utterances.speaker: HILLARY CLINTON, FORMER SECRETARY OF STATE
utterances.utterance: Probably. I mean, you know, it's -- it's hard to know. But I mean, if you're in the Iowa caucuses, and 41 percent of Democrats are socialists or self-described socialists, and I'm asked, "Are you a capitalist," and I say yes but with appropriate regulation and appropriate accountability, you know, that probably gets lost in "Oh, my gosh, she's a capitalist."

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Well, so people are like yes, another. We're like adding them up, #yetanotherexcuse. So what's going on here, Greg? Because I know you get delighted every time Hillary makes an appearance.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It's -- this one's especially hilarious, because she's right.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A large portion of the Democratic Party are sniveling socialists. They're for the universal-based income, higher taxes, drop-down control.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Sanders supporters.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Guaranteed jobs.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Guaranteed jobs. Identity over the individual. But they weren't voting for Trump. She was their only choice, so she shouldn't be complaining. And I don't think the Democratic Party would actually disagree with her on this. They do -- they are chasing a failed system. We have the most effective political economic -- economical system in the history of the world, but the Democrats are like Sideshow Bob. They keep walking into rakes. You know? And it's always going to be -- they're always going to move to socialism, and they're always going to fail.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. That was a good little synopsis.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Sideshow Bob walking into rakes?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, I know. That analogy was good. But I think we should move this excuse, maybe, to No. 1. It actually has some credence. Well done. Well done.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But it's a lie, too.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Well, that's true.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It is very instructive about what's going to happen in 2020.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Because the ground really shifted under Hillary Clinton's feet from when she ran in 2008 to 2016. In 2008, Bernie Sanders could not have run as an avowed socialist and won. If you think about the free-trade politics of JFK, a Bill Clinton, even a President Obama, everything had changed. And I don't what they're going to do in 2020, because if the economy is going -- well, it's going super well now. Can that continue to 2020? Probably for little while here. How are they going to make an argument that there should be something different? I think that will be very difficult. But if you look at a place like Ohio right now, it's a very heated gubernatorial race. The Bernie Sanders supporters are out there in force, you have a state that is actually pretty -- turning pretty red, and it's more likely that a Republican will be able to win both statewide contests with Senate and the governor's race.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right, indeed. It's interesting. Probably, like, seriously scribbling at home to come up with another idea. Because like, whoa, this tactic is not going to work. But it's true. You saw what was kind of the groundswell of support, Jesse, for Bernie Sanders, more progressive candidates, forcing the Democratic Party as a whole to tack further to the left and more progressive ideologies. A little bit of a pinch for him there.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes. Democrats like Bernie, because he fights for the poor and he looked poor. That really helps him. With the hair and everything like that. Democrats don't do well when they run really wealthy candidates. If you look at Gore, and Kerry, and Hillary. You've got to get someone like Bernie that's a little bit disheveled and can fight for the little guy. That's authentic. But honestly, "capitalism" is a dirty word for Democrats. They love socialism, but they can't define it. When you ask a Democrat -- and I do this on the street -- where has socialism worked? They can never say. Has it worked in Venezuela? Not so much.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They don't give you the old -- Finland.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: They will point to Sweden. Right, so they'll point to Sweden. OK. Sweden is fine if you want to be taken care of for the rest of your life, if you want to live a middle-class life. If you start with nothing in this country, you can have a yacht. In Sweden, that can never happen. The greatest part about America is there's upward mobility and grit, and that's rewarded. It's never going to be rewarded in Sweden. And that's why the Democrats get themselves in trouble, because they're always offering handouts instead of hand ups.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: That was, like, so weird. That was like an infomercial. "You, too, can get a yacht. Come to America."

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I just want to -- before I get to Juan. You know, there are some very good-looking poor people.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I was poor for a long time. I was poor for a long time.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I'm still more poor than you. And better looking.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Everyone was -- everyone was poor in college.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: You just proved your point.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right. Jesse really didn't mean that. Nevertheless, a mom text is going to be coming.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: She already hit me up for a poll I cited. She wanted it sourced, and she wanted the sample size.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: And margin of error. All right. Juan.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: In fact, you know, you are -- you were reciting Rasmussen, which is conservative leaning. They have almost half of Americans agreeing that we should have guaranteed jobs in this country.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, that scares me.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So I guess -- I guess they're socialists. But I mean, what you have at this moment in terms of income inequality is a heightened sense of concern. And people feeling "I got left behind. I'm never going to catch up. I can't get a house as good as my parents." But the key here is I remember you guys going after Hillary Clinton during the campaign for "Why doesn't she release her speeches to Wall Street?" Oh, so this part of the same attack initiated by Bernie Sanders, who came within one percentage point of tying Hillary Clinton in Iowa, a state where about half of the Democrats said they are -- they are self-described as socialists. And those numbers are national. If you especially look at young Democrats. But I think they're confusing socialism with populism of the Trump/Bernie Sanders style --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- which is really about speaking to economic needs in a nation where the opportunity for progress has been diminished because of income inequality.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Good point.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: All right, that's it for us now. Put a bow on it. Being Stormy Daniels's attorney doesn't appear to be enough for Michael Avenatti. His big plans, next. Stay with us.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Stormy Daniels's attorney, Michael Avenatti, is in fact, everywhere these days, or at least when it comes to being on TV. After new developments over a payment to his client, Avenatti was back on CNN, making bold proclamations.

utterances.speaker: MICHAEL AVENATTI, ATTORNEY FOR STORMY DANIELS
utterances.utterance: Every statement that I've made, every prediction in this case thus far, Don Lemon, has come true. I have been right. And I don't say that to be egotistical. I've been right all along.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It turns out CNN can't get enough of this guy. The Media Research Center finds that he was on that network 59 times in less than two months. That's almost once a day, for those bad at math, like me. Avenatti isn't hiding hid true intentions either.

utterances.speaker: AVENATTI
utterances.utterance: We're going to continue to use the media. I think we've used it with great success. And I've said that this entire process is all about results. And that's what we 're ultimately interested in.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And Stormy's attorney is telling "Vanity Fair" multiple networks are approaching him about having his own show. Avenatti also reportedly pitched MSNBC directly about joining. Juan, this guy is a publicity hound. You have to admit it.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Yes, he's using the press ably.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: And the press loves being used.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I don't know. You think he's --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: You know, Greg was talking about how Kim Jong-un is reading "Art of the Deal." I think in this case, Avenatti is following the Trump blueprint and how you use media to advance your political cause. And he's doing it ably, I must say. Now Giuliani is on the air all the time. Maybe he's picked up on this, too. How do you use media to advance this cause? Avenatti is effective. I think that's why they keep having them on. Because the Stormy Daniels story is real.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: He's a better self-promoter than he is a lawyer. Because I think, Kimberly, a judge is probably going to rule against Stormy Daniels, and she's going to have to pony up.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, well, and I wonder who is paying for all of this. Who is paying the attorney fees? And who's really behind all of it. It just makes you go "Hmm," like that. But you know, listen, he is loving it. It's his 15 minutes of fame. And he is really, like, working the machine to be able to get some results for himself. Oh, and then he has a client.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That's right. Forgot about her. Fifty-nine times. Dana, that's almost as much as you are on television.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Are you watching me a lot?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: "The Daily Briefing" every day.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes, but I'm actually -- that's one thing I would say, is it's actually -- Michael, it's a lot of work to have your own show. You don't just get to show up --

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: You don't just go on set.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: -- and, like, bloviate. I just want to know from them, what is the outcome they desire? I don't understand. And that's why there's speculation like this about possibly they want more money. I would actually love to know, what's the legal outcome you very much want? What would be the headline that would be the one you imagine in your dreams as the most important one so that we cam understand where you want to go with it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: I think it's money and fame and then to damage the president politically. What do you think, Greg?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: He has said that's --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Three years (ph).

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- he could unseat the president. Look, Juan is correct that he's using the media, but the difference is he's fulfilling a narrative that Trump didn't. Trump has made things exciting. He's filling up buckets that they need filled, and he's willing to cleave a country, to cut a -- to split a country in two to advance a career.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: But I have to hand it to him. This is what he wants to do. And the dupes are the media. And the media for the last I don't know how long has been saying it's America that was duped by Trump. No, it was the media that was duped by Trump, and now we're being duped by him.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, but they want to be, because they want the same outcome, result.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Except us, of course. The PC police are sure out in full force these days. Now they're going after "The Simpsons." Stick around.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: We told you about that prom dress controversy earlier this week. An uproar over a white teen in Utah wearing an Asian-style dress. Now the University of New Hampshire has decided to replace its Cinco de Mayo celebrations this Saturday with Unity Day so it doesn't, quote, "distress" its Latino students. And there's a race row with the longest running TV show in America, my favorite, "The Simpsons." Allegations that the character Apu is a stereotype of South Asian immigrants. Creator Matt Groening pushing back saying he's proud of the show and, quote, "I think it's time in our culture where people love to pretend that they're offended." Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes. I mean, that is. It's like we live in a world of, you know, perpetual offense. Like, everybody is offended about something at some point. When you wake up every morning, you just go, "I'm sorry. I'm sorry." Right? Because you don't know who you might particularly offend. People used to love "The Simpsons." Right? Very successful show. Now things are getting sort of picked apart. OK? Is this character bad? Is that character bad? I don't know. Do you have a problem with this character?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, no, I love "The Simpsons." And Apu is not a major character, but I must say, I'm struck by the idea that comes from the critics, Kimberly, that he's the only representation of a South Asian male on TV. And of course, it's not that, you know, convenience stores owner -- I think he runs the Quik-E-Mart on "The Simpsons" -- don't exist. The question is, is it a caricature of people who are striving immigrants?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Well, according to Joe Biden, everybody at 7-Eleven has an Indian accent. So I mean, we all remember that gaffe. Apu is not offensive. And if you want to play that game, Groundskeeper Willie is offensive to Scotch-Irish alcoholics.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: In the effort to be -- full disclosure here, my uncle works for the University of New Hampshire. I want to get that out of the way. Also, so the Latin community at the New Hampshire University is upset about Cinco de Mayo? Apparently, Cinco de Mayo is when the Mexicans beat the French. Now, that is a low bar. I'm not sure I would have a holiday if I beat the French.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No, you would probably be embarrassed, yes.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: That would be, like, and everyday thing for me. But they say that they're upset. It created this stress in the Latin community, to celebrate Cinco de Mayo. So I don't know --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: They're celebrating a win.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: They're celebrating a victory. Albeit a French -- over the French. But still --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Low bar. Low bar.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- be happy. Be happy.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So Dana --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: What a bizarre, bizarre analysis.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: -- the other side of the argument ably presented by Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Is there another side?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: The Latino community at the University of New Hampshire said, "Hey, you know, we don't like people walking around making fun of Mexican culture and the like." And then when they said this, it set off a series of racial incidents on campus, racist incidents like graffiti, swastikas, slurs, vandalism. And so now the college says, "We would like this to be a unifying event."

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: OK, then order up some margaritas and, you know, enjoy. Life is meant to be enjoyed, OK? Young people at the university, stop it. You're so privileged to live in this country and to be getting an education and to have a chance to know all sorts of people from all different cultures. Nobody is making fun of Hispanic culture by celebrating Cinco de Mayo. It's just a chance, an excuse to have a party.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Exactly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, no one is offended.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: A fiesta, for those of us who are watching.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Actually, who doesn't like guac and chips and salsa? That's my favorite food. Am I going to get accused of cultural appropriation?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I want to appropriate it. I wish the Puerto Ricans had a good, like, holiday like that. So I just go ahead and go with Cinco de Mayo.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I think -- you know what? I was looking around today at the stores for a paste-on mustache for Gregory.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why?

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: To --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: To do what?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: So you could culturally appropriate --

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Be in an adult movie?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, no. What is the -- the image of the guy on the coffee bag? Juan --

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Juan Valdez.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: A lot of this is --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: No one knows.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: -- born from the social justice movement, which are -- they literally have become the fun police. They're a humorless mob on every campus out to eliminate joy because they have none in their lives. Because the oppressive versus oppressed narrative has made them so incredibly angry that any cultural appreciation becomes appropriation. Bret Weinstein, he's a great professor -- Weinstein -- said it best. He says when you come face-to-face with a group of people who are devoid of all humor, then there is no potential for dialogue. And humor provides the good-natured kind of path to shared experience. We can make jokes with each other. Therefore, we understand each other. Without humor, you're going to end up with intolerance and ultimately, fascism. So if you can't have fun. You were talking about those hate crimes, which are almost always entirely hoaxes afterwards. They find out that the noose was placed by somebody else or the writing on the wall was done by somebody else. That's what happens. You can no longer meet -- the individuals because the groups say no.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, you know, I'm all for -- I'm all for fun. I'm all for Cinco de Mayo, but I'm not for making fun of minority students on the campus.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That's a daring, daring position.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Neither am I.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Is anybody for that?

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Well, I think you guys say -- we just see the fun.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: When I get out of "The Five," I go make fun of minorities, Juan. You can see me on the street.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Okie-doke. "One More Thing" is up next.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It's time now for "One More Thing" -- Kimberly.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Hello. Thank you Dana Perino, star of "The Daily Briefing." All right. Well, most people who go to a Pink concert, well, they're dancing their little heinies off, singing along and really living in the moment. But if you are six years old, that time might be better spent with a little nap or two, as evidenced by Pink's beautiful little daughter, 6- year-old Willow. She's struggling to keep her eyes open during her mom's Dallas concert, nodding off. Her dad, carrying her, films her. So she shared the adorable video on social media, Pink, did, and said, "I really rocked that show."

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: It looks like Juan when I am talking.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, exactly.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I pay attention to you, Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: It's unbelievable.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: It's like a shock and awe.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: I agree.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Juany.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: All right. So you guys know I'm a newspaper reporter at Heart. Well, take a look at this front page from the Chicago Sun-Times. That's right; it's blank. No news about the White House or the White Sox. The paper ran this bold front page to ask readers for their financial support, noting that news organizations that do original reporting now represent less than 3 percent of what you can find online in this country. And newspaper advertising, it's declining, taking money away from quality journalism. The situation is killing off papers all across the country. Denver especially comes to mind. Today is World Press Freedom Day. From me to you, love your local newspapers.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Yes.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Subscribe

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: That was racist.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: What?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: A white paper.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: It was all white.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Oh, my gosh.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Why couldn't it have been black, Juan? Jeez. I'm out of here.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: My friend Ian Bremmer has a new book out. It is called "Us Versus Them: The Failure of Globalism." And if you are a Trump supporter, I think you would want to check this book out. Even if you're not, it's a New York Times best seller, just made the list today.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I like him, too.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: He was talking about it on the show today, about just the feeling going on around the world. Watch. IAN BREMMER, AUTHOR, "US VS. THEM": Average people in the United States, like everyone I grew up with in the projects, feel like this country and the establishment no longer serves them. And that is true economically. It's true culturally. It's true in terms of our military. It's true in terms of technology. Those are deep, deep-seated things that are just not getting fixed. And we're not unique. This is the way they feel in Britain; it's the way they feel in Canada and in New Zealand.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Anyway, it's a great book. Check it out -- Jesse.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Do you guys remember that game Jenga?

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Love it.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Where you stack it, and you try to pull the things out? Well, check out this shot. This is a golf, Joshua Kelly. This is how he wins Jenga.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Chip shot into the middle of the Jenga Tower.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Perfect.

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: Takes out the middle piece. Look at that. You know how hard that is to do? Everybody that's played golf knows --

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Is this a fake video?

utterances.speaker: WATTERS
utterances.utterance: -- that's impossible. It's a trick shot video. It's not fake news, Kimberly. But thanks for challenging my integrity.

utterances.speaker: WILLIAMS
utterances.utterance: Wow.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: All right, Greg.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Just your vetting. Just your vetting.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: I know what you've been waiting for, this. It's time for --

utterances.speaker: GRAPHIC
utterances.utterance: Greg's Sleepy Cat News

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: "Greg's Sleepy Cat News." All right, we go to Wisconsin. Let's check out this sleepy cat. We actually have a sleepy cat copter. It goes around and finds sleepy cats and checks on them. Yes, he looks like he's asleep.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: It looks like Pink's daughter.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Yes, there he is. He's been listening to Juan talk about Trump. He's out. There he goes. Aww. I thought we had a better sleepy cat video. But that will do for now. Cats are always tired, and it's not like they do anything.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Have you ever been that tired?

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Get a job, cat. Then sleep.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: I was that tired when I came back from that week away.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: Yes, you were tired.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Hard time. And in the makeup chair.

utterances.speaker: GUILFOYLE
utterances.utterance: I'm out of here Friday.

utterances.speaker: GUTFELD
utterances.utterance: Great story, Dana.

utterances.speaker: PERINO
utterances.utterance: Thank you. I really like to help us so we can get through the time, because we have a little extra time, but no more. Set your DVRs. Never miss an episode of "The Five."
